description: {"blocks":[{"key":"5ondf","text":"DiOlistic labelling is a high-throughput technique commonly used to label neurons in fixed brain tissue using the fluorescent lipophilic carbocyanine dye, DiI. It labels a large population of neurons in a dense yet distributed pattern, making it ideal for morphological studies. However, DiOlistic labelling typically requires an expensive commercial gene gun. Therefore, our protocol presents a low-cost alternative using materials that are already available in most laboratories (e.g. a plastic 12-well culture plate lid) or easily acquired at a low price (e.g. a paintbrush). We detail the DiI labelling process, including the preparation, delivery, incubation, and post-processing steps. Overall, this protocol labels a large population of neurons in a dense yet distributed pattern and, therefore, is a simple and low-cost alternative to DiOlistic labelling.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"epgkj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

groups.title: A low-cost method for high-throughput DiI labelling of neurons in fixed brain tissue

guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"78dhv","text":"The step-by-step protocol only describes the DiI labelling process. This guidelines section provides reference information regarding the other procedures.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":3,"length":23},{"style":"bold","offset":45,"length":14},{"style":"bold","offset":73,"length":18},{"style":"bold","offset":101,"length":22},{"style":"bold","offset":137,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"12bhr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5nfci","text":"A typical workflow of the procedures involved: Tissue Preparation (Sectioning \u0026 Fixation) → DiI Labelling (DiI Preparation, DiI Delivery, DiI Incubation, \u0026 DiI Post-processing) → Tissue Mounting → Image Acquisition → Post-processing (e.g. deconvolution) → Morphological Reconstruction ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":47},{"style":"bold","offset":91,"length":1},{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":285}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ds56b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5krfd","text":"Tissue Preparation ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":19},{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2pekj","text":"This protocol used fresh, fixed adult rat brain tissue that was prepared by rapidly slicing into 800 µm coronal sections using a custom 3D printed brain slicer and fixed by immersing into 1.5% PFA in PB for 24 h at 4°C. The tissue was then stored in PBS at 4°C until DiI labelling (see the figure below). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":129,"length":30}],"data":{}},{"key":"4jr3e","text":"Various tissue preparation methods and sample types are compatible with this method. Depending on the sample type, fixation can be done with intracardial perfusion or by immersion fixation, but generally, lower aldehyde concentrations (1.5% or 2% PFA) are preferred over the traditional 4% PFA as higher concentrations impede DiI diffusion and the quality of labelling (although many protocols still use 4% PFA) (Cheng et al., 2014; Kim et al., 2007; Staffend \u0026 Miesel, 2011). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"28a6","text":"Most protocols use a vibratome to section the tissue, and most commonly use sections with a thickness of around 200-400 µm. The tissue sections tend to be thicker than traditional IHC methods to ensure the sampling of complete neurons/minimise truncations. Cryostats and freezing microtomes are avoided, as freezing will disrupt the cell membrane. Successful labelling impinges on an intact membrane (Gan et al., 2009). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"49c9j","text":"Methods for fixed samples: rat (Rasia-Filho et al., 2010), rats \u0026 mice (Foster-Olive et al., 2018), non-human primate \u0026 mice (Seabold et al., 2010), human (Das et al., 2019), and neuronal cultures (Cheng et al., 2014; Kashiwagi et al., 2019).  ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fhsup","text":"Unfixed samples can also be used (although less commonly). However, they require much shorter DiI incubation times, alternative post-processing procedures, and, of course, a shorter visualisation limit.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ckh66","text":"Methods for unfixed samples: fish \u0026 mice (O'Brien \u0026 Unwin, 2006), rat (acute slice preparation) (Hosokawa et al., 1992), \u0026 unfixed cultures (Honig \u0026 Hume, 1986). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bv253","text":"It is crucial to note that the tissue's surrounding environment, especially during sectioning and fixation, can cause extraneous changes to the dendritic morphology. See the following literature (Bourne et al., 2007; Dehghani et al., 2018; Fiala et al., 2003; Idziak et al., 2023; Kim et al., 2007; Kirov et al., 2004; Korogod et al., 2015; Park et al., 1996; Tao-Cheng et al., 2007).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5d4bb","text":"Try to control for these factors as much as possible. However, if not possible, at least ensure the preparation conditions are systematic and consistent amongst experimental samples and be aware that these artifacts can arise.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1qp1","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"e01na","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cgqrc","text":"DiI Labelling ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":14},{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cmp9r","text":"We strongly recommend reviewing the provided notes and video and conducting a pilot study or at least working with test samples before proceeding to experimental samples.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"48j5e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"jrfj","text":"DiI labelling can be combined with other procedures, such as:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":61}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cph7n","text":"Multi-colour labelling  - Multi-colour labelling can be achieved by combining combinations of DiI, DiO, and DiI as in the original DiOlistic labelling study (see Gan et al., 2000; Gan et al., 2009). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ecliu","text":"Immunofluorescence - DiI labelling can be coupled with immunofluorescence techniques; however, some modifications may be needed. Particular care should be taken regarding the permeabilization reagent and tissue thickness (see Matsubayashi et al., 2008; Neely et al., 2009; Staffend \u0026 Miesel, 2011). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4ng5m","text":"Tissue Clearing - Tissue clearing may be helpful for thick optical sections. Many tissue clearing methods are incompatible with lipophilic dyes, like DiI, mainly due to the delipidation steps. However, there are DiI-compatible methods available (see reviews by Richardson \u0026 Lichtman, 2015; Tian et al., 2021).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"557iu","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2h3do","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"esi0t","text":"Tissue Mounting","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15},{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"r1j6","text":"For our 800 µm thick brain tissue slices, we developed a temporary mounting method allowing imaging of both sides. We used a glass-bottom imaging dish (ibidi µ-Dish 35 mm, high, #1.5) with a washer-weighted coverslip to minimize the distance between the sample and the coverslip. This setup allowed easy flipping of the tissue for imaging of both sides (see figure below).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"afguk","text":"We used a mounting media containing a mix of ½ glycerol and ½ PBS with 2.5% DABCO antifade (refractive index (RI) ~1.41, matching the RI of the silicone immersion oil of the objective lens). The mounting media also had a mild clearing effect due to its similarity to fixed brain tissue's RI. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8d74m","text":"However, the DiI-labelled tissue was not left in the mounting media for extended periods as glycerol has a dye-bleeding effect on membrane dyes like DiI (Cheng et al., 2014; Murphy \u0026 Fox, 2007). Still, many protocols use glycerol-based mounting media (Gan et al., 2009; Kim et al., 2007; Staffend \u0026 Miesel, 2011) or commercial glycerol containing mounting medias such as Prolong Gold (Cheng et al., 2014; Seabold et al., 2010) or Vectashield (Trivino-Paredes et al., 2019).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fb9sd","text":"Also note that some mounting media, particularly hard-setting ones, can induce tissue shrinkage and compression, potentially altering the neuronal morphology (see interesting discussion thread). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":175,"length":17}],"data":{}},{"key":"b2ek9","text":"Traditional mounting and coverslipping can be used for thinner tissue sections featured in other protocols (sometimes with a spacer in between to avoid crushing the tissue) (Foster-Olive et al., 2018; Heck et al., 2012; Rasia-Filho et al., 2010). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ngrv","text":"However, it is crucial to note optimisation of the mounting parameters is paramount to successful imaging, especially when it comes to imaging small structures like dendritic spines (see Banecelin et al., 2021; Dumitriu et al., 2011; Foster Olive et al., 2018; Kashiwagi et al., 2019; Peterson et al., 2015). As such, it is essential to minimise the effect of spherical aberrations as much as possible (Diel et al., 2020; Murray, 2011)! ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9k1vh","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":4,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"a85ga","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9vi91","text":"Image are beyond the scope of this protocol, however, some relevant resources \u0026 literature are listed {"blocks":[{"key":"4m9p7","text":"Using a pair of metal forceps, take a small piece of a shredded Kimwipe and carefully blot the excess PBS from the tissue surface via capillary action. Hold the glass dish and tilt it towards yourself to aid in drawing the liquid away. Avoid directly blotting over the region of interest and overdrying it.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3nt39","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e1frd","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"e60gt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":21,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"67ljo","text":"Excess surface liquid prevents the DiI from penetrating \u0026 adhering to the brain tissue. ","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bnfi1","text":"The Kimwipe is shredded into small pieces so no sharp corners can poke the tissue \u0026 the jagged edges help draw the liquid away. ","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4krb3","text":"The tissue slice should still appear a bit shiny and not matte. ","type":"ordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7di47","text":"Storage - Clasp the dried DiI-coated well plate lid onto the accompanying well plate, wrap it in foil, and store it in a dry, dark cupboard or drawer at  until further use (use within 2 weeks). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":26,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":152,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"oh0j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eaa37","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9m3ab","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"3981DE97592D11EFB5EA0A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"","unit":32}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":19,"offset":4,"style":"bold"},{"length":16,"offset":24,"style":"italic"}],"key":"4b1og","text":"For longer-term storage (e.g. \u003e 1 month), place in an airtight ziplock bag or container with a silica desiccant packet. ","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4jv7l","text":"Exposure to moisture prevents DiI transfer \u0026 exposure to light causes fading.","type":"ordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"lma6","text":"Rotate the plate 180º. Flip over the paintbrush and drag the unused side of the bristles onto the unused half of the DiI-coated well lid as described in step 8   . Then repeat steps 8.1 and 8.2 (this will be DiI delivery to edge 2 - see figure 6). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":153,"length":6},{"style":"bold","offset":176,"length":9},{"style":"bold","offset":190,"length":4},{"style":"bold","offset":223,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":160,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ctl0h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"gotostep","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"104C4E00A3374CB3B7233B31D99C90D7","step_guid":"A8273A9AE5FB4AF38D0335DA129CB3CE","title":""}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ac9gt","text":"Position the paintbrush parallel to the tissue slice, about 2 cm above it, with the bristle tips aligned with the slice's top edge. Use a pair of metal forceps to gently tap the brush's ferrule, dislodging and sprinkling DiI onto the tissue. Between taps, move the brush forward and backward for even dispersion (tap for ~10 s).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fnsm1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9lnir","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"chi0t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":39,"offset":209,"style":"italic"}],"key":"donj7","text":"We use a pair of metal forceps to tap the brush because it has a bit of weight behind it. This makes it quite effective at dislodging the DiI from the bristles. However, anything slightly heavy will work, too (e.g. a scalpel handle or metal ruler).","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5dmt8","text":"Starting off with gentle taps is important; if not, all the DiI will be dislodged at once.","type":"ordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7209s","text":"Take a paintbrush (see materials section \u0026 the note below for more information) and load the DiI onto one side of the bristle tips by dragging them across half a DiI well lid in a short, smooth stroke. Try to apply even pressure across the bristles and avoid the edges/condensation ring of the well lid. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":18,"length":61}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1bnu8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ck76e","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6dgub","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"brmpa","text":"Moving the bristles back \u0026 forth across the well lid will encourage DiI clumping.","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9sc3d","text":"If the bristles are too flexible, pinch the section close to the ferrule for better maneuverability.","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":14,"offset":164,"style":"italic"}],"key":"62c6b","text":"Make sure the prepared DiI \u0026 the paintbrush are fully dry! Otherwise, the DiI crystals will struggle to latch onto the bristles \u0026 also struggle to detach from them (see figure 7).  ","type":"ordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3msto","text":"For more coverage, rotate the slice 90º and then 180º, repeating steps 8, 8.1, and 8.2 (this will be DiI delivery to edges 3 and 4 - see figure 6). Before doing so, either use a new brush or clean the brush by wiping the bristles on a clean Kimwipe and tapping to remove the excess DiI (this is to prevent clumping).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":65,"length":14},{"style":"bold","offset":83,"length":3},{"style":"bold","offset":117,"length":8},{"style":"bold","offset":129,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"28hli","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8s8gk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a5g2m","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"f6hpv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"guid":"6FBEFEAC43DF11EF9D1A0A58A9FEAC02","height":274.58363636363623,"id":491534,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"8nu77\",\"text\":\"Figure 6. Schematic of the DiI delivery sequence (4 edges of the tissue).\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":73},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":9}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"protocols_io_delivery_seq_edge.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/q2h8cdnaf.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/raaqcdnaf.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/raapcdnaf.webp","width":505.086956521739}},"1":{"type":"result","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"djbgd","text":"The bristles should appear pink \u0026 the well lid should appear streaky after DiI delivery!","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"je1b","text":" ","type":"atomic"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9qse8","text":"If not, then it may be that the paintbrush \u0026/or well lids were not dry enough. ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8gscl","text":"Or, the bristles were too soft \u0026/or sparse to effectively load the DiI crystals. ","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"alt":"","guid":"D418966D554211EF90F70A58A9FEAC02","height":176.79272727272723,"id":491536,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"8hlsm\",\"text\":\"Figure 7. The paintbrush bristles \\u0026 DiI well lids after delivery. a) Pink dye residue on the tips of the bristles. b) A used DiI well lid. The unused areas appear as a dusty magenta colour, while the used areas appear as faint purple streaks. c) The same well lid under a darker background. \",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":291},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":10},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":66,\"length\":2},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":115,\"length\":2},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":243,\"length\":2}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":"step-50D365E1D5C84A19839314DDF36B2263-nested-draft-a5g2m","original_name":"brush\u0026lid_after_app_v2_320dpi.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/q8v3cdnaf.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/raascdnaf.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/raarcdnaf.webp","width":522.7741935483871},"mutability":"IMMUTABLE","type":"image"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"504jg","text":"OPTIONAL: CHECKING THE DENSITY OF LABELLING (1-2 h after DiI delivery)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":44},{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":70}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"64eft","text":"Carefully remove the labelled slice and mount it onto a glass-bottom imaging dish with plenty of PBS to avoid drying whilst viewing. Afterwards, return to the well and resume the incubation process. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bshg5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"82t2i","text":"If the labelling is too sparse, the slice can be relabelled by repeating the processes above. However, the additional handling may damage the tissue, so we typically do not relabel.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":7,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9fang","text":"Instead, we recommend first becoming proficient with the delivery technique using test samples. Do this by carefully documenting the DiI delivery process and the resulting labelling pattern, then repeating until the desired pattern is consistently obtained. Each time, make small adjustments to the technique and then see how it affects the pattern of neuronal labelling. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3bhsf","text":"Once mastered, you will be able to perform the DiI delivery with the unaided eye and achieve consistently high-quality labelling. You will not need to perform labelling checks or relabel the tissue.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8gfc3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1q1er","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"o91q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"result","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"d1093","text":"Ideally, you should see a dense pattern of tiny DiI spots distributed across the slice!","type":"align-left"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dd5jk","text":" ","type":"atomic"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"14vt6","text":"The pattern of DiI dispersion is comparable to that obtained with DiOlistic labelling. For a comparison, see Bevan et al. (2024), Wu et al. (2004), and Seabold et al. (2010). ","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":7,"offset":3,"style":"bold"},{"length":26,"offset":50,"style":"bold"},{"length":50,"offset":145,"style":"bold"}],"key":"9u1s6","text":"At 2 hours, neuronal labelling is incomplete, but signs of successful uptake should be clear. For example, neuronal projections should appear as small directed streaks radiating from the dye spot. However, not every spot will result in successful neuronal labelling. For example, some will land in the neuropil and result in a more diffuse spread. Or some will be too clumpy.","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":32,"offset":43,"style":"bold"}],"key":"emvbn","text":"If the majority of the dye spots appear as small, intensely saturated spots, then the DiI crystals may not have been successfully incorporated into the tissue because there was too much liquid on the surface during DiI delivery. ","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":13,"offset":28,"style":"bold"}],"key":"9omkr","text":"If most dye spots appear as diffuse blobs, then the tissue was likely damaged at some point.","type":"ordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"3E2BE957496111EF81960A58A9FEAC02","height":190.87272727272727,"id":491538,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"7m6jj\",\"text\":\"Figure 8. Coronal brain slice 2 hours after DiI labelling. The labelled slice was imaged with an inverted Olympus FV3000 laser scanning confocal microscope (CLSM). a) 1.25× objective lens in laser scanning mode (LSM). b) 1.25× objective lens in ocular mode. c) 10× objective lens in ocular mode. The ocular mode images were acquired using a cellphone camera attached to the eyepiece via a 3-D printed adaptor. Note that some spots appear diffuse because they are out of focus rather than damaged. \",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":9},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":164,\"length\":2},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":217,\"length\":3},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":258,\"length\":2},{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":497}],\"entityRanges\":[{\"key\":0,\"offset\":401,\"length\":7}],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{\"0\":{\"type\":\"link\",\"mutability\":\"MUTABLE\",\"data\":{\"guid\":\"47886F82E2004A189BAEC5E4D9B4F992\",\"url\":\"https://www.openocular.com/\"}}}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":"step-36C879658D394210A5E9BD6FCCA858E8-nested-draft-1q1er","original_name":"DiI 2h Slice Check ocular \u0026 LSM v2 600dpi.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/q4pbcdnaf.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/raaucdnaf.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/raatcdnaf.webp","width":580},"mutability":"IMMUTABLE","type":"image"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dnjrj","text":"Under the fumehood, remove the excess PBS from the well containing the labelled tissue and add   of 4% PFA. Incubate for 30 min. This does not completely stop it but drastically slows it down, which is important for maintaining crisp \u0026 clear neuronal labelling \u0026 prolonging the visualisation period.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"safety","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":88,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"138kc","text":"Use the appropriate PPE \u0026 follow the proper handling/disposal procedures when using PFA!","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"867r","text":"Add   DAPI solution to the well. Tilt the plate while incubating to ensure the solution fully covers the tissue (otherwise, use more DAPI solution or use smaller volume well plates, e.g. a 24-well plate).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":4,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6un7n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fl34g","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1tcge","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"400","error":false,"guid":"","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"94unb","text":"DAPI nuclei stain is used to visualise the neuroanatomical boundaries \u0026 assess the quality of the tissue slice. Other nuclei stains like Hoescht can be used if desired.","type":"ordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"c2hun","text":"Remove the PFA and rinse twice with PBS (1 min per wash).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"1inps","text":"Remove the DAPI and rinse twice with PBS (5 min per wash).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9rup1","text":"Either proceed to storage or tissue mounting. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":18,"length":8},{"style":"bold","offset":28,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cig8q","text":"For storage, place into a well filled with PBS, cover and wrap in foil, and store at 4°C.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":3,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2nu3l","text":"For tissue mounting, refer to the guidelines section for further information.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3gs0d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ohpr","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"25bum","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":12,"offset":18,"style":"bold"},{"length":7,"offset":40,"style":"bold"}],"key":"42k4n","text":"Be mindful of the refrigerator used for storage. Refrigerators with variable temperatures, such as freeze-thaw cycling, compromise the membrane integrity \u0026 the quality of the DiI labelling. ","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":22,"offset":36,"style":"bold"}],"key":"58f8","text":"If available, store the tissue in a lab-grade refrigerator with consistent, well-regulated temperatures. If not, it may be best to proceed immediately to tissue mounting \u0026 imaging. ","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":18,"offset":41,"style":"bold"},{"length":19,"offset":126,"style":"bold"}],"key":"dftbi","text":"For dendritic spine imaging, we find the optimal time frame for image acquisition to be between 24 hours to 4 days, while the visualisation limit is around 7 days after DiI labelling. This may be longer for larger features of interest, such as dendritic branching patterns.","type":"ordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bul6j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1rtrf","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7nbcq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"71mvm","text":"See the video demonstration \u0026 refer to the timestamps in the description bar. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":78}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5vnl2","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"26lbn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2g4l4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"30hqo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"alt":"","guid":"03BE9EC1592E11EFB5EA0A58A9FEAC02","height":290,"id":491540,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"81njf\",\"text\":\"Figure 5. Schematic of the DiI delivery process.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":48},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":9}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"working DiI app v2 (protocols io).png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/q958cdnaf.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/raawcdnaf.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/raavcdnaf.webp","width":580}},"1":{"type":"embed","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"align":"","code":"\u003ciframe title=\"YouTube video player\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/LtF5g5fkxdM?si=Yvl4wQZtgHyToDbx\" height=\"315\" width=\"560\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e"}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":14,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"bb5ab","text":"Tissue dryness - The tissue shown in the video is a bit overdried due to the extended filming time. Try to work faster, aiming for \u003c3 minutes!","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":13,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"5o87u","text":"Tapping time - The video shows the brush being tapped longer than necessary. Most of the DiI is dislodged in the initial taps to the brush - so the time can be reduced as indicated in the steps below. ","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":17,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"8meth","text":"Labelling pattern - The video shows broad coverage of the entire slice. Adjust your application pattern to focus on your specific region of interest.","type":"ordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"kfjg","text":"Vortex the solution intermittently for several minutes until no clumps remain. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c7is2","text":"Storage - Decant the prepared DiI solution into a dark/amber glass bottle, seal it, and wrap it with foil to protect it from light. Then, store the bottle at   until further use.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":158,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"clfo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ciju7","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4jnfb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":88,"offset":79,"style":"italic"}],"key":"3rlv1","text":"If desired, the solution can be split into smaller aliquots and tightly sealed (e.g. if used infrequently or concerned about evaporation or light exposure over time). ","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6hp7r","text":"The DiI stock solution is quite stable, and we usually use","type":"ordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{},"error_temperature":false,"guid":"A1884B6C3DB111EF8C690A58A9FEAC02","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"4","unit":10}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":90,"offset":79,"style":"italic"}],"key":"3rlv1","text":"If desired, the solution can be split into smaller aliquots and tightly sealed (e.g. if used infrequently or concerned about evaporation \u0026/or light exposure over time). ","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6hp7r","text":"The DiI stock solution is relatively stable. We have tested its use for up to 6 months.","type":"ordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8pgmi","text":"OPTIONAL: LABELLING THE OPPOSITE SIDE OF THE TISSUE ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":51},{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":52}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b5p86","text":"Repeat on the other side if desired, but make sure to re-moisten the tissue slice with PBS before picking it up. Also, make sure to flip it over onto a clean section of the glass plate to avoid picking up DiI crumbs dropped from the previous steps. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3h3pe","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2k6oj","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2drtl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"84pif","text":"Most methods do not label both sides because thinner tissue sections tend to be used, e.g. 200-400 µm thick slices.","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":42,"offset":138,"style":"italic"}],"key":"e93ea","text":"However, we labelled both sides as we used tissue sections that were ~800µm thick \u0026 imaged both sides with a non-permanent mounting setup (see the guidelines for more information).","type":"ordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2n5gv","text":"Next, vary the brush angle and distance (e.g., hold it perpendicular to the slice) and tap more firmly to dislodge the remaining DiI (tap for ~5 s).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4jbv0","text":"To clean the paintbrushes, fill a small container with ethanol and dip the DiI-coated bristles into it. Brush against the walls of the container to break up any remaining DiI and drag across a Kimwipe. Repeat this process once, then allow the brush to air-dry for 24 hours before reuse.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":3,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6p03s","text":"To clean a used DiI-coated well plate lid, pour ethanol over it and allow the DiI to dissolve. Wipe the lid clean with a Kimwipe, and repeat if necessary. Then rinse with ddH2O and air-dry before reuse.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":3,"length":38},{"style":"sub","offset":174,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9b7eb","text":"Examples of whole neurons","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":25},{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bmg6g","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1stcq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fpv8a","text":"Examples of dendritic segments","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":30},{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2m95p","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"cpad6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"etr70","text":"Figures 9a \u0026 9b illustrate the variation in the neuronal labelling patterns and sizes of the DiI crystals/spots produced by this method. Overall, a large population of neurons are randomly labelled.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":8,"length":2},{"style":"bold","offset":13,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d3gs5","text":"This method's labelling pattern allows the neuronal morphology to be clearly observed, as depicted by the diverse types in figure 9c. Moreover, the order and origin of the dendritic branches can be easily traced back to the soma, making it suitable for dendritic analyses (see figure 10).","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":129,"length":3},{"style":"bold","offset":284,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"231a1","text":"Of course, not every dye spot on the tissue results in neuronal labelling, perhaps due to DiI clumping, failure to incorporate into the tissue, tissue damage, or landing in the neuropil, etc. And not every labelled neuron will be suitable for sampling due to truncation (see figure 10d), insufficient labelling, perpendicular projections or projections beyond the working distance, being obscured by other features \u0026/or cells, etc. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":282,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"br83b","text":"The sampling criteria will differ depending on the features and analyses of interest. For example, dendritic spine imaging is rather complex and warrants further considerations that are beyond the scope of this protocol (see the literature listed in the guidelines for more information). ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ej5ho","text":"Nevertheless, this method labels a large population of neurons, with plenty suitable for sampling. The following literature provides a good starting point for guidelines on sampling - Dickstein et al. (2016), Dumitriu et al. (2011), and Wu et al. (2004). ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"alt":"","guid":"F7538D41560B11EFA2880A58A9FEAC02","height":293.1636363636364,"id":491542,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"fj7ra\",\"text\":\"Figure 9. Examples of neurons labelled with the DiI paintbrush method. Images were acquired using an Olympus FV3000 CLSM. a) A patch of cortical pyramidal neurons labelled with DiI taken with a 10× objective lens in ocular mode. The image was acquired by mounting a cellphone camera to the eyepiece with an adaptor. b) Lower-quality image stacks of neuron patches acquired with a 20× objective lens in LSM mode. The intensely saturated, irregularly shaped white spots are where the DiI crystals have landed. c) Higher-quality image stacks of whole neurons acquired with a 60× silicone oil immersion objective lens. The image stacks in b) \\u0026 c) are maximum intensity projections (MIP) displayed with look-up tables (LUTs) from the KTZ set colorful black to white via NeuroCyto LUTs in ImageJ. \",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":9},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":121,\"length\":3},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":316,\"length\":2},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":507,\"length\":3},{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":791}],\"entityRanges\":[{\"key\":0,\"offset\":307,\"length\":7},{\"key\":1,\"offset\":729,\"length\":31},{\"key\":2,\"offset\":765,\"length\":14},{\"key\":3,\"offset\":783,\"length\":6}],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{\"0\":{\"type\":\"link\",\"mutability\":\"MUTABLE\",\"data\":{\"guid\":\"D5B1FACB550F11EFBC530A58A9FEAC02\",\"url\":\"https://www.openocular.com/oe2\"}},\"1\":{\"type\":\"link\",\"mutability\":\"MUTABLE\",\"data\":{\"guid\":\"89A1371381E14D02A23F5C0E2A456A3F\",\"url\":\"https://github.com/kwolbachia/KTZ-LUTs\"}},\"2\":{\"type\":\"link\",\"mutability\":\"MUTABLE\",\"data\":{\"guid\":\"8B6DE5EBC39745DC8B8F86CED18D7FA8\",\"url\":\"https://sites.imagej.net/NeuroCyto-LUTs/\"}},\"3\":{\"type\":\"link\",\"mutability\":\"MUTABLE\",\"data\":{\"guid\":\"2DA0FBD28E7F42589BC8376FC399D8B9\",\"url\":\"https://imagej.net/\"}}}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"neuronspane_v2.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/q9becdnaf.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/raaycdnaf.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/raaxcdnaf.webp","width":580}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"alt":"","guid":"2FF809DC560C11EFA2880A58A9FEAC02","height":179.27272727272728,"id":491544,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"e731h\",\"text\":\"Figure 10. Examples of dendritic segments. Image stacks were acquired using an Olympus FV3000 CLSM. a) A terminal basal dendritic segment covered in spines \\u0026 an axon with boutons from a cortical pyramidal neuron. b) Thorny excrescences from a dendritic segment of a hippocampal CA3 pyramidal neuron. b) A terminal apical tuft from a cortical pyramidal neuron densely covered in dendritic spines with complex morphologies. d) Dendritic segments from extremely truncated cortical pyramidal neurons. The arrows indicate the notching. Truncated dendritic segments at the tissue surface often show aberrant notching (\\u0026 possibly swelling), similar to dendritic varicosities seen after neuronal injury. These truncated surface segments appear to provide \\\"high-quality\\\" image stacks due to intense labelling \\u0026 less axial blurring compared to the deeper segments from intact neurons. Although tempting to sample, these truncated segments should be avoided as they introduce confounds. All images were acquired with a sampling pixel of 50 nm \\u0026 z-step of 150 nm using a 60× silicone oil immersion objective lens \\u0026 then deconvolved in CellSens using either 25 iterations of the fast maximum likelihood algorithm (a) or 20 iterations of the advanced maximum likelihood algorithm with noise reduction (b,c,d). Following deconvolution, the z-series were stacked in ImageJ \\u0026 presented as greyscale MIP with a 1 \\u0026 5 µm scale bar.  \",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":11},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":100,\"length\":2},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":213,\"length\":2},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":300,\"length\":2},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":422,\"length\":2},{\"style\":\"italic\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":1414}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"dendrites_v4.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/q9bhcdnaf.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/raa2cdnaf.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/raazcdnaf.webp","width":580}}}}
